body: By modules, you mean the sub-directories touched, right? Like finding the number of directories in which files got changed?

I meant modules, which are described at https://wiki.mozilla.org/Modules/All.
But actually, let's use components instead, as they're easier to retrieve, see https://mozilla-version-control-tools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/hgmo/mozbuildinfo.html.

Unfortunately, they are not as easy to retrieve as I was expecting, so I'll remove the `good first issue` label from this.

rename.from: Add number of modules touched as a feature
rename.to: Add number of components touched as a feature

issue.title: Add components touched as a feature

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

body: The info can be retrieved by using mach, e.g. `./mach file-info bugzilla-component toolkit/components/telemetry/`.

So it is like parsing the commit's patch_data, similar to what we are doing in `repository.py`, and taking the file names from there to find the file's info using mach, right?

I tested this for a commit in mozilla-central:
```
(py27) F:\COMPILED\Mercurial\mozilla-central>python ./mach file-info bugzilla-component build/moz.configure/bindgen.configure
Firefox Build System :: General
  build/moz.configure/bindgen.configure
```

But can we use mach in our code? Any suggestions how we can do that?

Yes, we can use the `subprocess` library to execute mach.
The `file-info` command also has a `--format` option to return a json instead of plain text, which might be better.
Moreover, you can pass a list of files, you don't need to pass one at a time.
Actually, even better, by running `./mach file-info bugzilla-component **/* --format json` you should get info on all files in the repository. So you'd just need to run mach once.

N.B.: In theory, we should run mach after checking out to the required commit, as files can be removed/renamed, or components can change, but as an approximation we can start by running `mach` in the repository at the "current state" (which is the latest commit).

But we need the components touched by a specific commit in our data right?

Wouldn't `./mach file-info bugzilla-component **/* --format json` give the info for all files in the repository irrespective of the fact that they were changed by a commit or not?
You can run that script, put the result in a map, then for each commit you get the list of modified files and you go into that map to get the components.
(BTW `**/*` only gives first-level files, we'll need another way to get all files)

The script doesn't seem to work, it returns an empty dict:
```
(py27) F:\COMPILED\Mercurial\mozilla-central>python ./mach file-info bugzilla-component **/* --format json
{}
```
Try running "./mach" without python. If it doesn't work still, try running "./mach bootstrap" first.

issue.title: Add components touched and number of components touched as features

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

body:
I'm able to run `./mach file-info bugzilla-component **/* --format json` using `mozilla-build` shell script.
I'll make the changes in the PR.

issue.title: Add number of previous commits touching the same modules as a feature

issue.body:
This is similar to https://github.com/mozilla/bugbug/commit/a002e0ce53080699a78cada08a95fd2355953c42#diff-fd96da16451dabb38a55be1721e8be9e, but for components.

It's a little harder than author or reviewer experience, as we need to parse the patch in order to get the components, and we're currently parsing the patches in multiple processes.
